original: All students are different in terms of their cognitive styles , learning levels and achievements as well as motivation , personality , and pace of learning .<CONCAT>When there are students with varied levels in English , it may be challenging for teachers to prepare for or deliver the course .<CONCAT>Here are some of my solutions for this issue .<CONCAT>First of all , determining the needs of the students is always the top priority .<CONCAT>While conducting a need analysis , you can have a general picture of learners ' motivation in learning English .<CONCAT>After that , teachers are supposed to use partnership and grouping exercises and activities in order to meet individual 's needs .<CONCAT>Through teamwork , students with varied levels can cooperate and learn from each other through discussions .<CONCAT>It is beneficial for both the upper and lower achiever because they can assist or get help from each other .<CONCAT>Differentiated instructions , giving different tasks for the same activity , are proved to be necessary in a class with varied levels of students .<CONCAT>Teachers can assign tasks which have different levels of difficulty , or different numbers of tasks to students with different levels .<CONCAT>Moreover , instead of using a core textbook , or using different levels of textbooks , carrying out a theme - based approach is more appropriate , and it also saves teachers ' preparation time .<CONCAT>Finally , preparing supplementary for both the upper or lower level of students , so that the higher achievers can stay excited and challenged , while the lower achiever can also learn by their own pace of learning .

original: Firstly , the immersion method takes its inspiration from the way in which we all learnt to speak our nature tongue : implicitly .<CONCAT>With this method , learners are simply exposed to the target language , either by going abroad to live in the country where it is spoken , or by having a native teacher .<CONCAT>There is no explicit focus on grammar ; instead , the learners are expected to " absorb " the language and its rules .<CONCAT>This method has its advantages , as it is the way we all learnt to speak , and so it is arguably more natural .<CONCAT>Another advantage is that students are unencumbered by overcomplicated , confusing metalanguage .

original: Secondly , the classroom method is the one with which most students ( especially if they are older ) are familiar .<CONCAT>Learners are normally taught in their mother tongue , and are given grammar rules , which they then apply to the language they are learning .<CONCAT>This method also has its benefits , not least logistically speaking , since many students do n't have access to native speakers or are not able to travel abroad .<CONCAT>Furthermore , some learners respond better to an explicit focus on rules , which make them aware of the mistakes they are making .

corrected: Have you ever stopped to think that some standards exist in society that everyone knows and follows although some people do it unconsciously ?<CONCAT>These standards are called unwritten rules , which can be defined as unspoken rules imposed in each culture to make the population live more civilly ( Bob Greene , How Unwritten Rules Circumscribe Our Lives - Paragraph 6 ) .<CONCAT>In fact , since the beginning , the written rules have helped to create civilizations , while the unwritten rules have helped to maintain them , allowing life to be more harmonious .<CONCAT>For example , I can cite the importance of the unwritten rules in my own culture , the Brazilian culture .<CONCAT>There are some aspects and actions that everyone who lives in Brazil needs to follow , and those directly reflect the values of Brazilian culture .

original: One of the most important unwritten rules that you should follow in Brazil is related to the vocal patterns .<CONCAT>When Olquin said that the situation and the environment define the correct tone of speech ( 1995 ) , he was talking about the African American Communication , but he is also describing the Brazilian communication at the same time .<CONCAT>Even though there is no definite consensus about the exact vocal patterns in Brazil , there are some facts about the extremes of it .<CONCAT>First , Brazilians feel uncomfortable when people close to them raise their tone of voice and continue speaking loudly during a long time , without they have clear reasons .<CONCAT>It means that you pretend to transform the dialog in a monolog ; moreover , unknown people in the same environment of you frequently do not want to know about your thinking .<CONCAT>Surprisingly , on the other hand , a speech too low is seen as an antisocial rule , and can be interpreted as an offense .<CONCAT>In Brazilian culture , if during a conversation a person speaks too low , the listener will assume that the speaker does not want to continue with the dialog or does not care about what you are talking .<CONCAT>In both the extremes of a speech , loud and low , there is a violation of the values of a good communication .<CONCAT>Therefore , when you are in a conversation , it is important to pay attention to execute with successful the unwritten rules of vocal patterns .
corrected: One of the most important unwritten rules that you should follow in Brazil is related to vocal patterns .<CONCAT>When Olquin said that the situation and the environment define the correct tone of speech ( 1995 ) , he was talking about African American Communication , but he is also describing Brazilian communication at the same time .<CONCAT>Even though there is no definite consensus about the exact vocal patterns in Brazil , there are some facts about the extremes of them .<CONCAT>First , Brazilians feel uncomfortable when people close to them raise their tone of voice and continue speaking loudly for a long time , without having clear reasons .<CONCAT>It means that you want to transform the dialog into a monolog ; moreover , unknown people in the same environment as you frequently do not want to know about your thinking .<CONCAT>Surprisingly , on the other hand , a speech too low is seen as an antisocial rule , and can be interpreted as an offense .<CONCAT>In Brazilian culture , if , during a conversation , a person speaks too low , the listener will assume that the speaker does not want to continue with the dialog or does not care about what you are saying .<CONCAT>In both the extremes of speech , loud and low , there is a violation of the values of good communication .<CONCAT>Therefore , when you are in a conversation , it is important to pay attention to comply with the unwritten rules of vocal patterns successfully .

corrected: Although Brazilians usually do not worry about distance made by others , people from different cultures believe that Brazilians spend a lot of time looking at others .<CONCAT>As a result , some people can make misinterpretations .<CONCAT>For example , in some cultures , Brazilians can be considered rude by women because they like to keep constant eye contact , and for these women , this means a lack of respect or invasion of privacy .<CONCAT>Differently , foreign men often believe that they are being desired due to this constant eye contact .<CONCAT>In general , this supposition is not regarded as true for many people in our culture , since Brazilians believe that constant eye contact is one of the most important points to maintain a good dialog .<CONCAT>According to the article " Nonverbal Communication : Speaking without Words " , eye contact is important because " insufficient eye contact can create communication barriers " .<CONCAT>In fact , in Brazil , eye contact is prime , and you will be considered to be without interest in the speaker or that the speaker is bothering you if you do not give enough attention when you are talking to them .<CONCAT>The source of this rule is easy to identify , especially when parents are talking to their kids ; it is hard to get the kid 's attention exclusively , but the parents insistently repeat , " look at me when I am talking to you " .<CONCAT>Therefore , this interaction demonstrates that eye contact can have a strong influence on the cultural values of attentiveness and respect for the others ' opinion .

corrected: According to Ferguson et al ( 2013 ) , dietary nitrate ( NO3- ) supplementation , via its reduction to nitrite ( NO2- ) and subsequent conversion to nitric oxide ( NO ) , reduces blood pressure .<CONCAT>Bond , Morton and Braakhuis ( 2012 ) also argue that nitrate is considered a potent vasodilator .<CONCAT>The reason for this is that the nitric oxide relaxes blood vessels and dilates them , which helps the blood flow more easily and lowers blood pressure .<CONCAT>Thus , the induced vasodilation may affect both systolic and diastolic blood pressure after exercise .<CONCAT>Nevertheless , a study by The New England Journal of Medicine claims that only diastolic blood pressure is affected by nitrate supplement , since they did not find in their study a significant change to systolic blood pressure after nitrate supplementation in healthy volunteers .<CONCAT>Surprisingly , the current study has found significant changes in both systolic and diastolic blood pressure post exercise .<CONCAT>Thus , the investment in research into the influence of nitrate supplementation should continue , the aim of which would be to improve sports performance and improve quality of life .
